title: 114_hr3727
content: The "Health Insurance Rate Review Act" is aimed at protecting consumers from excessive, unjustified, or unfairly discriminatory rates. The Health Insurance Rate Review Act aims to protect consumers from excessive, unjustified, or unfairly discriminatory rates by allowing states to impose additional requirements on health insurance issuers for rate review processes. The Secretary consults with the National Association of Insurance Commissioners and consumer groups in the rate review process. The Secretary determines which markets in each state the State insurance commissioner or relevant State regulator will undertake corrective actions based on their utilization of such actions. The Secretary also determines which markets they will undertake corrective actions in. The Secretary, in cooperation with the State insurance commissioner or State regulator, will take corrective actions for excessive, unjustified, or unfairly discriminatory rates by denying or modifying rates as necessary. The Secretary, in cooperation with the State insurance commissioner or State regulator, will take corrective actions for excessive, unjustified, or unfairly discriminatory rates by denying, modifying rates, or requiring rebates to consumers. Noncompliance may result in civil monetary penalties and disqualification as a qualified health plan. Regulatory authority is clarified to address potentially excessive, unjustified, or unfairly discriminatory practices. In cooperation with State regulators, the Secretary will address potentially excessive, unjustified, or unfairly discriminatory rates by taking corrective actions such as denying, modifying rates, or requiring rebates to consumers. Noncompliance may lead to penalties and disqualification as a qualified health plan. Regulatory authority is clarified to tackle such practices. Title XXVII of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include section 2723, with subsections addressing the insertion of section 2794 in various paragraphs. This amendment aims to regulate potentially excessive, unjustified, or unfairly discriminatory rates in health plans, with penalties for noncompliance. Regulatory authority is clarified to address such practices. The amendment to Title XXVII of the Public Health Service Act includes the insertion of section 2794 in various paragraphs to regulate rates in health plans. Penalties are imposed for noncompliance with the aim of addressing potentially unfair practices. Section 2794 is inserted into different sections of the Public Health Service Act to regulate health plan rates. Penalties are imposed for noncompliance to address unfair practices. Authorization of appropriations is provided for Act implementation. The amendments made by this section shall take effect on the date of enactment of this Act and shall be implemented with respect to health plans beginning not later than January 1, 2017.
